conclusion: Initially, both chambers have the same pressure p, volume V, and temperature T. The total volume of the cylinder is 2V.
The diaphragm is in equilibrium when the force due to the pressure difference across it equals the gravitational force acting on it.
Initially, the pressure is the same on both sides, so the diaphragm is at rest.
When the piston is moved upwards, the volume of the upper chamber increases, and the volume of the lower chamber decreases.
Let the volume of the lower chamber be V_0 when the gas starts to leak.
As the piston moves, the pressure in the lower chamber increases due to the reduced volume.
The pressure in the lower chamber when the gas starts to leak is given by p_0 = p + mg/V_0.
The pressure in the upper chamber decreases as its volume increases.
The volume of the upper chamber is 2V - V_0.
Using Boyle's Law (since the temperature is constant), the pressure in the upper chamber is p_1 = pV/(2V - V_0).
Gas starts to leak when the pressure in the lower chamber equals the pressure in the upper chamber: p_0 = p_1.
Substitute the expressions for p_0 and p_1: p + mg/V_0 = pV/(2V - V_0).
Rearrange the equation to solve for V_0: p(2V - V_0) + mg(2V - V_0)/V_0 = pV.
Multiply through by V_0: pV V_0 - pV_0^2 + 2mgV = mgV_0.
Rearrange into a quadratic equation: pV_0^2 + (mg - pV)V_0 - 2mgV = 0.
Use the quadratic formula V_0 = (-b ± sqrt(b^2 - 4ac))/(2a), where a = p, b = mg - pV, and c = -2mgV.
